p: The impact of lysosomotropic drug accumulation on cells is obvious: lysosomes increase in volume [ 14], lysosomal function is impaired leading to downregulation of autophagy [ 15, 16], endocytosis and the entire membrane trafficking in the cell is reduced [ 17]. Lysosomal and endosomal pH increases as a consequence of the overload of basic compounds [ 9, 18]. Due to the cationic drug binding to phospholipid bilayer and change of the surface bilayer charge, the degradation of phospholipids is slowed [ 12] resulting in the accumulation of excess phospholipid membrane and vesicles inside the cell, which may lead to an adverse effect known as phospholipidosis [ 19]. If not too extreme, all these effects on cells are reversible upon the cessation of drug treatment [ 20].
